com.martinandersson.javaee.utils

Class ThreadScheduler

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.martinandersson.javaee.utils.ThreadScheduler

  • public final class ThreadScheduler
extends Object
    A high-level thread scheduler, running provided "threads" by insertion-order and serially.

    A client-provided "thread" is more like a green thread; encapsulated in a Consumer<Yielder>. Each consumer provided to the enqueue(Consumer...) method is executed using a dedicated Thread instance not shared by other consumers.

    The consumer is referred to as a "stage". The client add statements to his stage and schedule the stage for execution using a ThreadScheduler. The stage is provided a ThreadScheduler.Yielder which the stage may use to cooperate with other stages by yielding the CPU to them.

    Only one stage may run at at any given time, and their order of execution is the same order as they were added to the scheduler.

    Unlike Thread.yield(), ThreadScheduler.Yielder.yield() is not a hint to the scheduler. If a stage invoke this method, then his executing thread shall be made dormant, kindly waiting for his turn. It is his turn again when all other stages (not yet completed) has been scheduled exactly once according to their enqueued order.

    For my part, I needed a tool that made it easy to schedule jobs run in different threads to ease testing/demonstration of overlapping transactions and their inter-transactional behavior. For example, I wanted T1 to lookup a JPA entity, then let T2 mutate state of the same JPA entity, only to provoke an OptimisticLockException when T1 was scheduled again to persist his version of the entity. In this case, mutating the version attribute can be done in other ways, but I've needed a more lenient and unobtrusive way to "program" sequential threads before and I believe that Java EE test code benefit substantially from this class. If code is supposed to execute in well defined steps across different threads, then only the semantics of a scheduler can make that test code reliable and trustworthy.

    This class is executable and provide code samples in public void static main().

    Author:
    Martin Andersson (webmaster at martinandersson.com)

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static interface  ThreadScheduler.Yielder
      A yielder provide method yield() that a stage may invoke to "yield" and let another stage begin or resume his execution path until that thread yield or die.

      Initializes a newly created ThreadScheduler with a specified thread factory.

    • Method Detail

      • enqueue

        public ThreadScheduler enqueue(Consumer<ThreadScheduler.Yielder>... stages)
        Enqueues a stage so that it may be executed by the scheduler.

        Same stage may be enqueued many times. One time or many, every provided stage will always be executed by his own unique worker thread.

        Parameters:
        stages - the stages
        Returns:
        self for chaining

      • enqueue

        public ThreadScheduler enqueue(Collection<Consumer<ThreadScheduler.Yielder>> stages)
        Enqueues stages so that it may be executed by the scheduler.

        Same stage may be enqueued many times. One time or many, every provided stage will always be executed by his own unique worker thread.

        Parameters:
        stages - the stages
        Returns:
        self for chaining

      • run

        public ThreadScheduler run()
                    throws InterruptedException
        Start executing all previously provided stages serially and in order.

        This method block until all stages has been executed whether they completed normally or one stage threw an exception. If a stage do throw an exception, then the exception is propagated to the caller of this method.

        As is the case with runtime exceptions during stage execution, if this thread is interrupted while waiting, then on best-effort basis, the remaining stages will not be scheduled again.

        Returns:
        self for chaining
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if fewer than two stages has been provided
        InterruptedException - if client's thread is interrupted while waiting

      • reset

        public ThreadScheduler reset()
        Will clear this scheduler of all stages, making him ready to accept new ones.

        Note that this method must be invoked between two calls to run().

        Returns:
        self for chaining

      • main

        public static void main(String... ignored)
                 throws InterruptedException
        Demonstrates how to use the ThreadScheduler class.
        Parameters:
        ignored - ignored
        Throws:
        InterruptedException - for simplicity only, should not happen
